div.p: SCOTISTS, a ſect of ſchool-divines and philoſophers, thus called from their founder J. Duns Scotus, a Scottiſh cordelier, who maintained the immaculate conception of the virgin, or that ſhe was born without original ſin, in oppoſition to Thomas Aquinas and the Thomiſts.

As to philoſophy, the Scotiſts were, like the Thomiſts, Peripatetics (fee Peripatetics); only diſtinguiſhed by this, that in each being, as many different qualities as it had, ſo many different formalities did they diſtinguiſh; all diſtinct from the body itſelf, and making as it were ſo many different entities; only theſe were metaphysical, and as it were ſuperadded to the being. The Scotiſts and Thomiſts likewiſe diſagreed about the nature of the divine co-operation with the human will, the meaſure of divine grace that is neceſſary to ſalvation, and other abſttruſe and minute queſtions, which it is needleſs to enumerate.
